message.content:
{"id": "269522", 
"title": "Bug 269522[handles] Cross reference view and markers mix up joinpoints assigned to advice", 
"description": "Bug 269522[handles] Cross reference view and markers mix up joinpoints assigned to advice", 
"OB": "In the cross reference view, when selecting one of the after advice statements, I see all of the joinpoints for both after advice. However, when selecting the other after advice statement, I see no joinpoints. Additionally, when I select the marker for either piece of after advice, I see all the joinpoints for both pieces of advice.", 
"EB": "The cross reference view should only display the joinpoints relevant to the selected after advice statement. Selecting one after advice statement should not affect the visibility of joinpoints associated with the other after advice statement. Similarly, selecting a marker should only display the joinpoints for the corresponding piece of after advice.", 
"SR": "Build ID: M200902111700

Steps To Reproduce:
1. Open and perform a clean compile on the attached project.
2. Open the cross reference view.
3. Select line 22 and observe that 5 joinpoints are displayed (there should only be 3).
4. Select line 68 and observe that no joinpoints are displayed (there should be 2).
5. Right-click the marker at line 68 and choose 'advises'. Observe that all 5 joinpoints are displayed.
6. Right-click the marker at line 22 and choose 'advises'. Observe that all 5 joinpoints are displayed."}

origin.input_prompt:
Your role is a senior software engineer, you are very good at analyzing and writing bug reports.
In your bug reports, it is essential to provide clear and informative statements for the following categories:
- **Observed Behavior (OB):** This section should describe the relevant software behavior, actions, output, or results. Avoid vague statements like "the system does not work."
- **Expected Behavior (EB):** This part should articulate what the software should or is expected to do, using phrases like "should...", "expect...", or "hope...". Avoid suggestions or recommendations for bug resolution in this section.
- **Steps to Reproduce (SR):** Include user actions or operations that can potentially lead to reproducing the issue. Use phrases like "to reproduce," "steps to reproduce," or "follow these steps."
It is possible that the bug report may lack sufficient details in the OB, EB, and SR sections. In such cases, your task is to infer the appropriate details based on the context and supplement the bug report to ensure it contains clear and complete OB/EB/SR statements. Also, improve the wording of these statements for clarity where possible.
To facilitate this process, please provide your responses in JSON format as follows:
{"id": "", "title": "", "description": "", "OB": "", "EB": "", "SR": ""}
origin.input_content:
<BUG REPORT>
{'id': '269522', 'title': 'Bug 269522[handles] Cross reference view and markers mix up joinpoints assigned to advice', 'description': 'Bug 269522[handles] Cross reference view and markers mix up joinpoints assigned to advice ', 'OB': '', 'EB': '', 'SR': 'Build ID: M200902111700Steps To Reproduce:I have two pieces of after advice in my aspect.In the cross reference view I see all of the joinpoints for both after advice selecting one of the after advice statements.When I select the other after advice statement I see no joinpoints.When I select the marker for either piece of after advice, I see all the joinpoints for both pieces of advice.1. open and perform a clean compile on the attached project2. open the xref view3. select line 22 an note that you see 5 joinpoints (should only be 3)4. select line 68 and note that you see zero joinpoints (should be 2 here)5. right click the marker at line 68 and choose "advises"note you see all 5 joinpoints6. right click the marker at line 22 and choose "advises"note you see all 5 joinpointsMore information: '}
